content: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <rdf:RDF xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns="http://purl.org/rss/1.0/" xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#"> <channel rdf:about="http://hdl.handle.net/1853/22422"> <title> NanoFANS Forum</title> <link>http://hdl.handle.net/1853/22422</link> <description>Biannual forum focusing on advanced nanobio systems</description> <items> <rdf:Seq> <rdf:li rdf:resource="http://hdl.handle.net/1853/45699"/> <rdf:li rdf:resource="http://hdl.handle.net/1853/45693"/> <rdf:li rdf:resource="http://hdl.handle.net/1853/44555"/> <rdf:li rdf:resource="http://hdl.handle.net/1853/44486"/> </rdf:Seq> </items> <dc:date>2015-03-15T23:12:11Z</dc:date> </channel> <item rdf:about="http://hdl.handle.net/1853/45699"> <title>Foodborne Pathogens and Toxin Detection from Food Matrix with Nanotechnology</title> <link>http://hdl.handle.net/1853/45699</link> <description>Foodborne Pathogens and Toxin Detection from Food Matrix with Nanotechnology Park, Bosoon The goal for the forum is to connect the medical/life sciences/biology and nanotechnology communities. The goal is to reach out researchers in the biomedical / life sciences areas and letting them know what nanotechnology can offer them in the advancement of their research. 2012 Fall Meeting of the NANOFANS Forum. Presented on November 20, 2012 from 11 am-2 pm in the Marcus Nanotechnology Building (Rooms 1116-1118) on the Georgia Tech campus.; Bosoon Park, PhD, is a member of the Faculty of Engineering at UGA and Research Scientist in the ARS Quality and Safety Assessment Research Unit, USDA, Athens, GA. His research interests are in the area of hyperspectral and real-time multispectral imaging and nanotechnology for food safety.; Runtime: 45:33 minutes </description> <dc:date>2012-11-20T00:00:00Z</dc:date> <dc:creator>Park, Bosoon</dc:creator> <dc:description>The goal for the forum is to connect the medical/life sciences/biology and nanotechnology communities. The goal is to reach out researchers in the biomedical / life sciences areas and letting them know what nanotechnology can offer them in the advancement of their research.</dc:description> </item> <item rdf:about="http://hdl.handle.net/1853/45693"> <title>Addressing NanoSensing for Current Food Practices \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Challenges of Scale for Samples and Sensors</title> <link>http://hdl.handle.net/1853/45693</link> <description>Addressing NanoSensing for Current Food Practices \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Challenges of Scale for Samples and Sensors Pierson, John 2012 Fall Meeting of the NANOFANS Forum. Presented on November 20, 2012 from 11 am-2 pm in the Marcus Nanotechnology Building (Rooms 1116-1118) on the Georgia Tech campus.; The focus for this presentation was "Nanotechnology in Food Safety".; John Pierson is a Principal Research Engineer with the Georgia Tech Research Institute. His research interests ad- dress environmental technologies in a broad range of industrial applications. With regard to food, his particular focus is on disinfection and flow cell development for food safety sensing . He has 20 years of experience related to poultry and food processing.; Runtime: 49:06 minutes </description> <dc:date>2012-11-20T00:00:00Z</dc:date> <dc:creator>Pierson, John</dc:creator> </item> <item rdf:about="http://hdl.handle.net/1853/44555"> <title>Development of a Safe and Biocompatible Nanoplatform</title> <link>http://hdl.handle.net/1853/44555</link> <description>Development of a Safe and Biocompatible Nanoplatform Qin, Dong 2012 Spring Meeting of the NANOFANS Forum. Presented on May 15, 2012 from 11 am-2 pm in the Marcus Nanotechnology Building (Rooms 1116-1118) on the Georgia Tech campus.; The focus for this presentation was "Nanotoxicology".; Dr. Qin is an Associate Professor in the School of Materials Science and Engineering at Georgia Tech. Her research interest centers on the cutting-edge research that bridges traditional fields of chemistry and materials science, with a focus on peculiar properties and applications enabled by materials and systems at the nanoscale.; Runtime: 35:05 minutes </description> <dc:date>2012-05-15T00:00:00Z</dc:date> <dc:creator>Qin, Dong</dc:creator> </item> <item rdf:about="http://hdl.handle.net/1853/44486"> <title>Nanomaterials in the Environment</title> <link>http://hdl.handle.net/1853/44486</link> <description>Nanomaterials in the Environment Klaine, Stephan 2012 Spring Meeting of the NANOFANS Forum. Presented on May 15, 2012 from 11 am-2 pm in the Marcus Nanotechnology Building (Rooms 1116-1118) on the Georgia Tech campus.; The focus for this presentation was "Nanotoxicology".; Dr. Stephan Klaine is a Professor at the School of Biological Sciences at the Clemson University. His research interests are in the behavior and effects of nanomaterials in aquatic ecosystems, environmental fate and effects of pesticides and metals, connections between fish brain chemistry and predator-prey behavior, environmentally sustainable development and impacts on aquatic ecosystems.; Runtime: 36:37 minutes </description> <dc:date>2012-05-15T00:00:00Z</dc:date> <dc:creator>Klaine, Stephan</dc:creator> </item> </rdf:RDF>
